Modern usage describes moody, emotionally unstable individuals whose unpredictability creates stress for those around them.
chineseExample_tr: 為一個喜怒無常的人工作令人精疲力竭。

example: Upon discovering the betrayal, he became furious beyond control.
chineseExample: 发现背叛后，他怒不可遏。
description: This idiom describes anger (怒) that cannot (不可) be suppressed (遏). It depicts rage so intense that it overwhelms all attempts at self-control. The phrase appeared in texts describing righteous fury at injustice or betrayal. Modern usage describes intense anger that demands expression, whether justified or not, and the loss of emotional regulation in extreme circumstances.
description_tr: This idiom describes anger (怒) that cannot (不可) be suppressed (遏). It depicts rage so intense that it overwhelms all attempts at self-control. The phrase appeared in texts describing righteous fury at injustice or betrayal. Modern usage describes intense anger that demands expression, whether justified or not, and the loss of emotional regulation in extreme circumstances.
chineseExample_tr: 發現背叛後，他怒不可遏。

example: The children's faces lit up when they saw the presents.
chineseExample: 孩子们看到礼物时喜笑颜开。
description: This idiom describes being so happy (喜) that one smiles (笑) and the face (颜) opens up (开). It captures the physical transformation that genuine joy brings to facial expression. The phrase depicts pure happiness visible in one's countenance. Modern usage describes obvious happiness that shows clearly on someone's face, the kind of joy that cannot be hidden.
description_tr: This idiom describes being so happy (喜) that one smiles (笑) and the face (顏) opens up (開). It captures the physical transformation that genuine joy brings to facial expression. The phrase depicts pure happiness visible in one's countenance. Modern usage describes obvious happiness that shows clearly on someone's face, the kind of joy that cannot be hidden.
chineseExample_tr: 孩子們看到禮物時喜笑顏開。

example: He described his adventure with animated enthusiasm.
chineseExample: 他眉飞色舞地描述着自己的冒险经历。
description: This idiom describes eyebrows (眉) flying (飞) and expression (色) dancing (舞). It captures the animated facial expressions of someone excited or enthusiastic. The vivid imagery of moving eyebrows and dancing features depicts obvious enjoyment. Modern usage describes animated enthusiasm, the visible excitement when someone talks about something they love or find thrilling.
description_tr: This idiom describes eyebrows (眉) flying (飛) and expression (色) dancing (舞). It captures the animated facial expressions of someone excited or enthusiastic. The vivid imagery of moving eyebrows and dancing features depicts obvious enjoyment. Modern usage describes animated enthusiasm, the visible excitement when someone talks about something they love or find thrilling.
chineseExample_tr: 他眉飛色舞地描述著自己的冒險經歷。

example: Receiving the good news, her whole face lit up with happiness.
chineseExample: 收到好消息，她眉开眼笑。
description: This idiom describes brows (眉) opening (开) and eyes (眼) smiling (笑). It depicts the full facial expression of genuine happiness where both brows relax upward and eyes crinkle with joy. The phrase captures authentic emotion visible across the entire face. Modern usage describes obvious happiness, the kind of joy that involves the whole face and cannot be faked.
description_tr: This idiom describes brows (眉) opening (開) and eyes (眼) smiling (笑). It depicts the full facial expression of genuine happiness where both brows relax upward and eyes crinkle with joy. The phrase captures authentic emotion visible across the entire face. Modern usage describes obvious happiness, the kind of joy that involves the whole face and cannot be faked.
chineseExample_tr: 收到好消息，她眉開眼笑。

example: He's been looking gloomy ever since he heard about the budget cuts.
chineseExample: 自从听说预算削减后，他一直愁眉苦脸。
description: This idiom describes worried (愁) brows (眉) and a bitter (苦) face (脸). It depicts the physical manifestation of anxiety and unhappiness in facial expression. The furrowed brow and downturned expression signal distress. Modern usage describes visible worry or displeasure, someone whose face clearly shows they are troubled or unhappy about something.
description_tr: This idiom describes worried (愁) brows (眉) and a bitter (苦) face (臉). It depicts the physical manifestation of anxiety and unhappiness in facial expression. The furrowed brow and downturned expression signal distress. Modern usage describes visible worry or displeasure, someone whose face clearly shows they are troubled or unhappy about something.
chineseExample_tr: 自從聽說預算削減後，他一直愁眉苦臉。

example: The losing team walked off the field dejected and dispirited.
chineseExample: 输球的队伍垂头丧气地走下球场。
description: This idiom describes a drooping (垂) head (头) and lost (丧) spirit (气). It depicts the body language of defeat and discouragement - the slumped posture of someone who has given up hope. The phrase captures how disappointment manifests physically. Modern usage describes dejection, the visible loss of energy and hope following failure or bad news.
description_tr: This idiom describes a drooping (垂) head (頭) and lost (喪) spirit (氣). It depicts the body language of defeat and discouragement - the slumped posture of someone who has given up hope. The phrase captures how disappointment manifests physically. Modern usage describes dejection, the visible loss of energy and hope following failure or bad news.
chineseExample_tr: 輸球的隊伍垂頭喪氣地走下球場。

example: She walked into the interview with confidence.
chineseExample: 她昂首挺胸地走进面试室。
description: This idiom describes holding the head (首) high (昂) and the chest (胸) out (挺). It depicts confident, proud posture that shows self-assurance. The phrase captures how confidence manifests in body language. Modern usage describes walking or standing with visible confidence, the posture of someone who believes in themselves and faces challenges boldly.
description_tr: This idiom describes holding the head (首) high (昂) and the chest (胸) out (挺). It depicts confident, proud posture that shows self-assurance. The phrase captures how confidence manifests in body language. Modern usage describes walking or standing with visible confidence, the posture of someone who believes in themselves and faces challenges boldly.
chineseExample_tr: 她昂首挺胸地走進面試室。

example: A good leader welcomes constructive criticism.
chineseExample: 好的领导者闻过则喜，欢迎建设性批评。
description: This idiom describes hearing (闻) faults (过) and then (则) rejoicing (喜). It comes from Mencius praising Yu the Great who welcomed criticism as opportunities for improvement. The phrase embodies the ideal attitude toward feedback. Modern usage praises those who genuinely appreciate criticism, understanding that identifying faults is the first step to self-improvement.
description_tr: This idiom describes hearing (聞) faults (過) and then (則) rejoicing (喜). It comes from Mencius praising Yu the Great who welcomed criticism as opportunities for improvement. The phrase embodies the ideal attitude toward feedback. Modern usage praises those who genuinely appreciate criticism, understanding that identifying faults is the first step to self-improvement.
chineseExample_tr: 好的領導者聞過則喜，歡迎建設性批評。

example: She readily accepts good suggestions from her team.
chineseExample: 她从善如流，乐于接受团队的好建议。
description: This idiom describes following (从) what is good (善) like (如) flowing water (流). It comes from Zuozhuan describing Duke Huan of Jin who accepted good advice as naturally as water flows downhill. The phrase praises adaptability in accepting wisdom. Modern usage describes people who readily adopt good ideas without ego resistance, flowing toward improvement naturally.
description_tr: This idiom describes following (從) what is good (善) like (如) flowing water (流). It comes from Zuozhuan describing Duke Huan of Jin who accepted good advice as naturally as water flows downhill. The phrase praises adaptability in accepting wisdom. Modern usage describes people who readily adopt good ideas without ego resistance, flowing toward improvement naturally.
chineseExample_tr: 她從善如流，樂於接受團隊的好建議。

example: The researcher worked tirelessly on her project for years.
chineseExample: 研究人员孜孜不倦地工作了多年。
description: This idiom describes working diligently (孜孜) without (不) becoming weary (倦). The doubled character 孜 emphasizes continuous effort. The phrase praises sustained dedication that doesn't diminish over time. Modern usage describes tireless workers who maintain their diligence and enthusiasm despite long hours or years of effort, never losing their drive.
description_tr: This idiom describes working diligently (孜孜) without (不) becoming weary (倦). The doubled character 孜 emphasizes continuous effort. The phrase praises sustained dedication that doesn't diminish over time. Modern usage describes tireless workers who maintain their diligence and enthusiasm despite long hours or years of effort, never losing their drive.
chineseExample_tr: 研究人員孜孜不倦地工作了多年。

example: The mentor skillfully guided the students through difficult concepts.
chineseExample: 导师循循善诱，带领学生理解困难的概念。
description: This idiom describes guiding (循循) skillfully (善) and leading (诱). It comes from the Analects where Yan Hui praised Confucius' teaching method of systematic, patient guidance. The doubled 循 emphasizes the gradual, step-by-step approach. Modern usage describes excellent teaching methodology - patient, systematic instruction that leads students to understanding without force.
description_tr: This idiom describes guiding (循循) skillfully (善) and leading (誘). It comes from the Analects where Yan Hui praised Confucius' teaching method of systematic, patient guidance. The doubled 循 emphasizes the gradual, step-by-step approach. Modern usage describes excellent teaching methodology - patient, systematic instruction that leads students to understanding without force.
chineseExample_tr: 導師循循善誘，帶領學生理解困難的概念。

example: Despite explaining it many times, she remained patient with the students.
chineseExample: 尽管解释了很多遍，她仍然诲人不倦。
description: This idiom describes teaching (诲) people (人) without (不) weariness (倦). It comes from the Analects where Confucius described his tireless dedication to education. The phrase embodies the ideal teacher who maintains enthusiasm despite repetition. Modern usage praises patient educators who never tire of helping others learn, maintaining dedication regardless of how many times they must explain.
description_tr: This idiom describes teaching (誨) people (人) without (不) weariness (倦). It comes from the Analects where Confucius described his tireless dedication to education. The phrase embodies the ideal teacher who maintains enthusiasm despite repetition. Modern usage praises patient educators who never tire of helping others learn, maintaining dedication regardless of how many times they must explain.
chineseExample_tr: 儘管解釋了很多遍，她仍然誨人不倦。

example: Good teachers adapt their methods to each student's learning style.
chineseExample: 好老师会因材施教，根据每个学生的学习方式调整方法。
description: This idiom describes teaching (施教) according to (因) ability (材). It embodies Confucius' educational philosophy of tailoring instruction to individual students' talents and needs. The phrase recognizes that different people learn differently. Modern usage praises adaptive teaching methods that recognize individual differences and adjust accordingly for optimal learning outcomes.
description_tr: This idiom describes teaching (施教) according to (因) ability (材). It embodies Confucius' educational philosophy of tailoring instruction to individual students' talents and needs. The phrase recognizes that different people learn differently. Modern usage praises adaptive teaching methods that recognize individual differences and adjust accordingly for optimal learning outcomes.
chineseExample_tr: 好老師會因材施教，根據每個學生的學習方式調整方法。

example: The scholarship program aims to make education accessible to all.
chineseExample: 奖学金项目旨在有教无类，让所有人都能接受教育。
description: This idiom describes having (有) education (教) without (无) categories (类). It comes from the Analects expressing Confucius' principle that education should be available regardless of social class. He accepted students from all backgrounds. Modern usage advocates for equal educational opportunity regardless of wealth, status, or background - education as a universal right.
description_tr: This idiom describes having (有) education (教) without (無) categories (類). It comes from the Analects expressing Confucius' principle that education should be available regardless of social class. He accepted students from all backgrounds. Modern usage advocates for equal educational opportunity regardless of wealth, status, or background - education as a universal right.
chineseExample_tr: 獎學金項目旨在有教無類，讓所有人都能接受教育。

meaning: Teach by words and personal example
example: The best parents teach not just through words but through their actions.
chineseExample: 最好的父母言传身教，不仅用言语更用行动教导孩子。
description: This idiom describes teaching through words (言传) and personal example (身教). It recognizes that instruction involves both verbal teaching and modeling behavior. Actions often teach more powerfully than words. Modern usage emphasizes the importance of practicing what one preaches, recognizing that children and students learn as much from observing behavior as from formal instruction.
description_tr: This idiom describes teaching through words (言傳) and personal example (身教). It recognizes that instruction involves both verbal teaching and modeling behavior. Actions often teach more powerfully than words. Modern usage emphasizes the importance of practicing what one preaches, recognizing that children and students learn as much from observing behavior as from formal instruction.
chineseExample_tr: 最好的父母言傳身教，不僅用言語更用行動教導孩子。

meaning: Peaches and plums fill the gate
example: The retired professor has trained hundreds of successful scholars.
chineseExample: 退休教授桃李满门，培养了数百名成功的学者。
description: This idiom describes peaches (桃) and plums (李) filling (满) the gate (门). Students are metaphorically called peach and plum trees because teachers cultivate them like gardeners. A teacher with many successful students has peaches and plums everywhere. Modern usage describes successful educators whose former students have achieved great things.
description_tr: This idiom describes peaches (桃) and plums (李) filling (滿) the gate (門). Students are metaphorically called peach and plum trees because teachers cultivate them like gardeners. A teacher with many successful students has peaches and plums everywhere. Modern usage describes successful educators whose former students have achieved great things.
chineseExample_tr: 退休教授桃李滿門，培養了數百名成功的學者。

example: She returned from vacation looking refreshed and happy.
chineseExample: 她度假回来春风满面。
description: This idiom describes spring wind (春风) filling (满) the face (面). It depicts someone whose face radiates warmth and happiness like the pleasant spring breeze. The phrase captures the appearance of contentment and good fortune. Modern usage describes someone who looks happy and satisfied, whose good mood or good fortune is visible in their pleasant expression.
description_tr: This idiom describes spring wind (春風) filling (滿) the face (面). It depicts someone whose face radiates warmth and happiness like the pleasant spring breeze. The phrase captures the appearance of contentment and good fortune. Modern usage describes someone who looks happy and satisfied, whose good mood or good fortune is visible in their pleasant expression.
chineseExample_tr: 她度假回來春風滿面。

example: The army maintained strict discipline, not disturbing the civilians.
chineseExample: 军队纪律严明，对百姓秋毫无犯。
description: This idiom describes not (无) violating (犯) even the finest autumn hair (秋毫). Autumn down refers to the tiny new hairs animals grow for winter - extremely fine. The phrase describes perfect discipline where not even the smallest thing is taken or disturbed. Modern usage describes scrupulous honesty and discipline, strict adherence to rules that doesn't allow even minor violations.
metaphoric_meaning: Show strict discipline; not take anything
description_tr: This idiom describes not (無) violating (犯) even the finest autumn hair (秋毫). Autumn down refers to the tiny new hairs animals grow for winter - extremely fine. The phrase describes perfect discipline where not even the smallest thing is taken or disturbed. Modern usage describes scrupulous honesty and discipline, strict adherence to rules that doesn't allow even minor violations.
chineseExample_tr: 軍隊紀律嚴明，對百姓秋毫無犯。

example: His straightforward character earned him everyone's trust.
chineseExample: 他光明磊落的性格赢得了大家的信任。
description: This idiom describes being bright (光明) and upright (磊落). The character 磊 shows three stones stacked, representing solidity and openness. The phrase depicts someone with nothing to hide, whose character is transparent and honorable. Modern usage describes people of integrity whose actions can withstand scrutiny, who act openly without hidden agendas.
description_tr: This idiom describes being bright (光明) and upright (磊落). The character 磊 shows three stones stacked, representing solidity and openness. The phrase depicts someone with nothing to hide, whose character is transparent and honorable. Modern usage describes people of integrity whose actions can withstand scrutiny, who act openly without hidden agendas.
chineseExample_tr: 他光明磊落的性格贏得了大家的信任。

example: He lived his life with nothing to hide or regret.
chineseExample: 他活得坦坦荡荡，无愧于心。
description: This idiom describes being open (坦坦) and broad (荡荡). The doubled characters emphasize the degree of openness and freedom from anxiety. It depicts someone who has nothing to hide and faces life with clear conscience. Modern usage describes people who live honestly and openly, whose transparency allows them to face anything without guilt or fear.
description_tr: This idiom describes being open (坦坦) and broad (蕩蕩). The doubled characters emphasize the degree of openness and freedom from anxiety. It depicts someone who has nothing to hide and faces life with clear conscience. Modern usage describes people who live honestly and openly, whose transparency allows them to face anything without guilt or fear.
chineseExample_tr: 他活得坦坦蕩蕩，無愧於心。

example: She is genuine - the same person in public and private.
chineseExample: 她表里如一，在公众场合和私下是同一个人。
description: This idiom describes the outside (表) and inside (里) being as (如) one (一). It depicts consistency between one's public persona and private self, between words and actions. The phrase values authenticity and integrity. Modern usage praises those who are genuine - the same person regardless of audience or circumstance, without pretense or duplicity.
description_tr: This idiom describes the outside (表) and inside (裡) being as (如) one (一). It depicts consistency between one's public persona and private self, between words and actions. The phrase values authenticity and integrity. Modern usage praises those who are genuine - the same person regardless of audience or circumstance, without pretense or duplicity.
chineseExample_tr: 她表裡如一，在公眾場合和私下是同一個人。

example: A good leader practices what they preach.
chineseExample: 好的领导者言行一致。
description: This idiom describes words (言) and actions (行) being consistent (一致). It values the alignment between what one says and what one does. The phrase warns against hypocrisy where promises don't match behavior. Modern usage emphasizes integrity and reliability, the trustworthiness that comes when someone's actions consistently match their words.
description_tr: This idiom describes words (言) and actions (行) being consistent (一致). It values the alignment between what one says and what one does. The phrase warns against hypocrisy where promises don't match behavior. Modern usage emphasizes integrity and reliability, the trustworthiness that comes when someone's actions consistently match their words.
chineseExample_tr: 好的領導者言行一致。

example: He kept his promise because he believed a man's word is his bond.
chineseExample: 他信守承诺，因为他相信一言既出，驷马难追。
description: This idiom describes once (既) a word (一言) is spoken (出). It is often paired with 驷马难追 (four horses cannot catch it) to emphasize that spoken words cannot be taken back. The phrase stresses the weight of verbal commitments. Modern usage emphasizes the importance of being careful with promises, as words once spoken create obligations that must be honored.
metaphoric_meaning: A promise once made must be kept
description_tr: This idiom describes once (既) a word (一言) is spoken (出). It is often paired with 駟馬難追 (four horses cannot catch it) to emphasize that spoken words cannot be taken back. The phrase stresses the weight of verbal commitments. Modern usage emphasizes the importance of being careful with promises, as words once spoken create obligations that must be honored.
chineseExample_tr: 他信守承諾，因為他相信一言既出，駟馬難追。

example: The manager handled the conflict with complete transparency.
chineseExample: 经理开诚布公地处理了冲突。
description: This idiom describes opening (开) sincerity (诚) and spreading (布) fairness (公). It originated from descriptions of Zhuge Liang's governance style - transparent and impartial. The phrase embodies ideal leadership that combines honesty with fairness. Modern usage describes candid, transparent communication and fair dealing that hides nothing and treats everyone equitably.
description_tr: This idiom describes opening (開) sincerity (誠) and spreading (布) fairness (公). It originated from descriptions of Zhuge Liang's governance style - transparent and impartial. The phrase embodies ideal leadership that combines honesty with fairness. Modern usage describes candid, transparent communication and fair dealing that hides nothing and treats everyone equitably.
chineseExample_tr: 經理開誠布公地處理了衝突。

meaning: Livers and galls illuminate each other
example: The two friends shared everything with complete trust.
chineseExample: 两位朋友肝胆相照，完全信任彼此。
description: This idiom describes livers (肝) and galls (胆) illuminating (照) each other (相). In Chinese culture, these organs represent courage and sincerity. The phrase depicts friends so close they share their innermost selves. Modern usage describes deep friendship characterized by complete trust and transparency, relationships where nothing is hidden and total loyalty exists.
description_tr: This idiom describes livers (肝) and galls (膽) illuminating (照) each other (相). In Chinese culture, these organs represent courage and sincerity. The phrase depicts friends so close they share their innermost selves. Modern usage describes deep friendship characterized by complete trust and transparency, relationships where nothing is hidden and total loyalty exists.
chineseExample_tr: 兩位朋友肝膽相照，完全信任彼此。

example: They had a heart-to-heart talk about their concerns.
chineseExample: 他们推心置腹地谈论了彼此的担忧。
description: This idiom describes pushing (推) one's heart (心) and placing (置) it in another's belly (腹). It depicts such trust that one metaphorically gives their heart to another for safekeeping. The phrase captures the deepest level of trust and intimacy. Modern usage describes completely open, honest communication where one shares their innermost thoughts and feelings without reservation.
metaphoric_meaning: Speak from the heart; confide completely
description_tr: This idiom describes pushing (推) one's heart (心) and placing (置) it in another's belly (腹). It depicts such trust that one metaphorically gives their heart to another for safekeeping. The phrase captures the deepest level of trust and intimacy. Modern usage describes completely open, honest communication where one shares their innermost thoughts and feelings without reservation.
chineseExample_tr: 他們推心置腹地談論了彼此的擔憂。

example: They became partners because they shared the same vision.
chineseExample: 他们志同道合，因此成为合作伙伴。
description: This idiom describes having the same (同) aspirations (志) and aligned (合) paths (道). It depicts people united by shared goals and values rather than mere proximity or convenience. The phrase emphasizes ideological and purposeful alignment. Modern usage describes like-minded people who come together because of shared vision, values, or goals - the foundation of strong partnerships and movements.
metaphoric_meaning: Share the same goals and values
description_tr: This idiom describes having the same (同) aspirations (志) and aligned (合) paths (道). It depicts people united by shared goals and values rather than mere proximity or convenience. The phrase emphasizes ideological and purposeful alignment. Modern usage describes like-minded people who come together because of shared vision, values, or goals - the foundation of strong partnerships and movements.
chineseExample_tr: 他們志同道合，因此成為合作夥伴。

example: From their first meeting, they knew they were kindred spirits.
chineseExample: 从第一次见面，他们就知道彼此情投意合。
description: This idiom describes feelings (情) being cast together (投) and ideas (意) matching (合). It depicts natural compatibility where both emotions and thoughts align. The phrase captures the experience of meeting someone who just fits. Modern usage describes instant rapport, the rare experience of finding someone whose temperament and thinking naturally harmonize with one's own.
metaphoric_meaning: Be perfectly compatible; hit it off
description_tr: This idiom describes feelings (情) being cast together (投) and ideas (意) matching (合). It depicts natural compatibility where both emotions and thoughts align. The phrase captures the experience of meeting someone who just fits. Modern usage describes instant rapport, the rare experience of finding someone whose temperament and thinking naturally harmonize with one's own.
chineseExample_tr: 從第一次見面，他們就知道彼此情投意合。

example: Despite their different backgrounds, they became the closest of friends.
chineseExample: 尽管背景不同，他们成为了莫逆之交。
description: This idiom describes a friendship (交) without (莫) opposition (逆). It comes from Zhuangzi describing friends whose relationship has no discord or conflict. The phrase depicts ideal friendship where understanding is so complete that disagreement doesn't arise. Modern usage describes best friends whose bond transcends ordinary friendship, characterized by perfect understanding and harmony.
description_tr: This idiom describes a friendship (交) without (莫) opposition (逆). It comes from Zhuangzi describing friends whose relationship has no discord or conflict. The phrase depicts ideal friendship where understanding is so complete that disagreement doesn't arise. Modern usage describes best friends whose bond transcends ordinary friendship, characterized by perfect understanding and harmony.
chineseExample_tr: 儘管背景不同，他們成為了莫逆之交。

example: They pledged loyalty to each other through thick and thin.
chineseExample: 他们是刎颈之交，发誓同甘共苦。
description: This idiom describes a friendship (交) of severed necks (刎颈). It comes from the story of Lian Po and Lin Xiangru who reconciled their enmity and became friends willing to die for each other. The phrase represents the highest level of loyal friendship. Modern usage describes friends so devoted they would sacrifice everything for each other, the ultimate bond of loyalty.
description_tr: This idiom describes a friendship (交) of severed necks (刎頸). It comes from the story of Lian Po and Lin Xiangru who reconciled their enmity and became friends willing to die for each other. The phrase represents the highest level of loyal friendship. Modern usage describes friends so devoted they would sacrifice everything for each other, the ultimate bond of loyalty.
chineseExample_tr: 他們是刎頸之交，發誓同甘共苦。

example: The elderly couple supported each other through their difficult years.
chineseExample: 这对老夫妻在困难岁月里相濡以沫。
description: This idiom describes moistening each other (相濡) with foam (以沫). From Zhuangzi's parable of fish in a drying pond who keep each other alive by sharing their foam. Though Zhuangzi suggested freedom was better, the phrase came to represent devoted mutual support during hardship. Modern usage describes couples or friends helping each other survive difficult times through mutual care.
description_tr: This idiom describes moistening each other (相濡) with foam (以沫). From Zhuangzi's parable of fish in a drying pond who keep each other alive by sharing their foam. Though Zhuangzi suggested freedom was better, the phrase came to represent devoted mutual support during hardship. Modern usage describes couples or friends helping each other survive difficult times through mutual care.
chineseExample_tr: 這對老夫妻在困難歲月裡相濡以沫。

example: Their long marriage was built on mutual respect.
chineseExample: 他们的婚姻长久，建立在相敬如宾的基础上。
description: This idiom describes respecting each other (相敬) like guests (如宾). It comes from Zuozhuan describing an ideal married couple who maintained the courtesy usually reserved for guests. The phrase depicts marriages where respect never fades into familiarity. Modern usage describes relationships, especially marriages, characterized by enduring mutual respect and courtesy.
description_tr: This idiom describes respecting each other (相敬) like guests (如賓). It comes from Zuozhuan describing an ideal married couple who maintained the courtesy usually reserved for guests. The phrase depicts marriages where respect never fades into familiarity. Modern usage describes relationships, especially marriages, characterized by enduring mutual respect and courtesy.
chineseExample_tr: 他們的婚姻長久，建立在相敬如賓的基礎上。

example: Their relationship exemplifies mutual respect and devotion.
chineseExample: 他们的关系是举案齐眉的典范。
description: This idiom describes raising (举) a food tray (案) level (齐) with one's eyebrows (眉). It comes from the story of Meng Guang who showed deep respect for her husband Liang Hong by always raising his food tray to eye level when serving him. Modern usage describes marriages characterized by deep mutual respect and devotion, where partners honor each other.
metaphoric_meaning: Married couple with great mutual respect
description_tr: This idiom describes raising (舉) a food tray (案) level (齊) with one's eyebrows (眉). It comes from the story of Meng Guang who showed deep respect for her husband Liang Hong by always raising his food tray to eye level when serving him. Modern usage describes marriages characterized by deep mutual respect and devotion, where partners honor each other.
chineseExample_tr: 他們的關係是舉案齊眉的典範。

meaning: White heads together in old age
example: They wished the newlyweds a lifetime of happiness together.
chineseExample: 他们祝愿新婚夫妇白头偕老。
description: This idiom describes white (白) heads (头) together (偕) in old age (老). It depicts couples who grow old together, their hair turning white side by side. The phrase is a common blessing at weddings. Modern usage expresses wishes for lasting marriages, the hope that couples will remain devoted until both have grey hair, symbolizing lifelong companionship.
description_tr: This idiom describes white (白) heads (頭) together (偕) in old age (老). It depicts couples who grow old together, their hair turning white side by side. The phrase is a common blessing at weddings. Modern usage expresses wishes for lasting marriages, the hope that couples will remain devoted until both have grey hair, symbolizing lifelong companionship.
chineseExample_tr: 他們祝願新婚夫婦白頭偕老。

example: The couple understood each other without words.
chineseExample: 这对夫妻心心相印，不用言语就能理解对方。
description: This idiom describes hearts (心心) imprinting (印) on each other (相). Originally a Buddhist term describing the transmission of dharma between master and disciple without words, it now primarily describes deep romantic connection. Modern usage depicts intimate understanding between lovers or close friends where communication transcends words - minds that think alike and hearts that beat as one.
metaphoric_meaning: Be perfectly attuned to each other
description_tr: This idiom describes hearts (心心) imprinting (印) on each other (相). Originally a Buddhist term describing the transmission of dharma between master and disciple without words, it now primarily describes deep romantic connection. Modern usage depicts intimate understanding between lovers or close friends where communication transcends words - minds that think alike and hearts that beat as one.
chineseExample_tr: 這對夫妻心心相印，不用言語就能理解對方。

example: He fell in love with her the moment he saw her.
chineseExample: 他第一眼见到她就一见钟情。
description: This idiom describes at one (一) glance (见) feelings (情) concentrate (钟). It captures the experience of instant romantic attraction where love strikes at first sight. The phrase appeared in classical literature describing sudden, overwhelming romantic feelings. Modern usage describes love at first sight, the powerful experience of immediate, intense attraction that feels destined.
description_tr: This idiom describes at one (一) glance (見) feelings (情) concentrate (鍾). It captures the experience of instant romantic attraction where love strikes at first sight. The phrase appeared in classical literature describing sudden, overwhelming romantic feelings. Modern usage describes love at first sight, the powerful experience of immediate, intense attraction that feels destined.
chineseExample_tr: 他第一眼見到她就一見鍾情。

example: She promised to love him forever, no matter what happens.
chineseExample: 她承诺无论发生什么，都会爱他到海枯石烂。
description: This idiom describes seas (海) drying up (枯) and stones (石) rotting (烂). These are impossibilities that would take eternity - seas don't dry and stones don't rot. The phrase represents eternal commitment. Modern usage in romantic contexts expresses undying love, promises that will last until the impossible happens - essentially forever.
metaphoric_meaning: Until the end of time; eternal love
description_tr: This idiom describes seas (海) drying up (枯) and stones (石) rotting (爛). These are impossibilities that would take eternity - seas don't dry and stones don't rot. The phrase represents eternal commitment. Modern usage in romantic contexts expresses undying love, promises that will last until the impossible happens - essentially forever.
chineseExample_tr: 她承諾無論發生什麼，都會愛他到海枯石爛。

example: May your friendship last forever.
chineseExample: 愿你们的友谊天长地久。
description: This idiom describes heaven (天) being long (长) and earth (地) being enduring (久). From the Dao De Jing describing the eternal nature of heaven and earth. The phrase represents permanence and eternity. Modern usage expresses wishes for lasting relationships, whether romantic, friendly, or familial - blessings for bonds that endure like heaven and earth.
description_tr: This idiom describes heaven (天) being long (長) and earth (地) being enduring (久). From the Dao De Jing describing the eternal nature of heaven and earth. The phrase represents permanence and eternity. Modern usage expresses wishes for lasting relationships, whether romantic, friendly, or familial - blessings for bonds that endure like heaven and earth.
chineseExample_tr: 願你們的友誼天長地久。

meaning: Hard to part, hard to leave
example: The farewell was emotional as neither wanted to say goodbye.
chineseExample: 告别时他们难分难舍，都不想说再见。
description: This idiom describes being hard (难) to part (分) and hard (难) to leave (舍). It depicts the pain of separation when attachment is strong. The doubled structure emphasizes the difficulty of saying goodbye. Modern usage describes the emotional difficulty of parting from loved ones, the reluctance to end a meeting or relationship when feelings run deep.
description_tr: This idiom describes being hard (難) to part (分) and hard (難) to leave (捨). It depicts the pain of separation when attachment is strong. The doubled structure emphasizes the difficulty of saying goodbye. Modern usage describes the emotional difficulty of parting from loved ones, the reluctance to end a meeting or relationship when feelings run deep.
chineseExample_tr: 告別時他們難分難捨，都不想說再見。

example: The children reluctantly left the amusement park.
chineseExample: 孩子们依依不舍地离开游乐园。
description: This idiom describes lingering (依依) and being unwilling (不舍) to leave. The doubled 依 emphasizes the clinging, reluctant quality of the departure. The phrase captures the hesitation when leaving something beloved. Modern usage describes reluctant partings - children leaving fun places, lovers saying goodbye, or leaving any situation one wishes could continue.
description_tr: This idiom describes lingering (依依) and being unwilling (不捨) to leave. The doubled 依 emphasizes the clinging, reluctant quality of the departure. The phrase captures the hesitation when leaving something beloved. Modern usage describes reluctant partings - children leaving fun places, lovers saying goodbye, or leaving any situation one wishes could continue.
chineseExample_tr: 孩子們依依不捨地離開遊樂園。

example: She kept looking back as she left her childhood home.
chineseExample: 离开童年的家时，她恋恋不舍地频频回望。
description: This idiom describes being attached (恋恋) and unwilling (不舍) to leave. Similar to 依依不舍 but with stronger emotional attachment through the character 恋 (love, attachment). Modern usage describes leaving places, people, or experiences one loves, the deep reluctance born from genuine attachment rather than mere habit.
description_tr: This idiom describes being attached (戀戀) and unwilling (不捨) to leave. Similar to 依依不捨 but with stronger emotional attachment through the character 戀 (love, attachment). Modern usage describes leaving places, people, or experiences one loves, the deep reluctance born from genuine attachment rather than mere habit.
chineseExample_tr: 離開童年的家時，她戀戀不捨地頻頻回望。

example: Her homeland remained constantly in her thoughts.
chineseExample: 她魂牵梦萦地想念着故乡。
description: This idiom describes the soul (魂) being pulled (牵) and dreams (梦) being haunted (萦). It depicts longing so intense it occupies both waking and sleeping thoughts. The phrase captures obsessive yearning. Modern usage describes missing someone or something so deeply that thoughts of them pervade consciousness - the homesick, the lovesick, anyone consumed by longing.
description_tr: This idiom describes the soul (魂) being pulled (牽) and dreams (夢) being haunted (縈). It depicts longing so intense it occupies both waking and sleeping thoughts. The phrase captures obsessive yearning. Modern usage describes missing someone or something so deeply that thoughts of them pervade consciousness - the homesick, the lovesick, anyone consumed by longing.
chineseExample_tr: 她魂牽夢縈地想念著故鄉。

meaning: Think in morning, yearn at night
example: He constantly thinks about his family back home.
chineseExample: 他朝思暮想着远方的家人。
description: This idiom describes thinking (思) in the morning (朝) and yearning (想) at night (暮). It depicts constant preoccupation from dawn to dusk. The phrase captures the experience of having someone or something always on one's mind. Modern usage describes intense longing that fills all hours, whether for absent loved ones, unreached goals, or lost opportunities.
description_tr: This idiom describes thinking (思) in the morning (朝) and yearning (想) at night (暮). It depicts constant preoccupation from dawn to dusk. The phrase captures the experience of having someone or something always on one's mind. Modern usage describes intense longing that fills all hours, whether for absent loved ones, unreached goals, or lost opportunities.
chineseExample_tr: 他朝思暮想著遠方的家人。

example: After years abroad, he returned to his hometown to retire.
chineseExample: 在海外多年后，他落叶归根，回到家乡退休。
description: This idiom describes falling (落) leaves (叶) returning (归) to their roots (根). Just as leaves fall and nourish the tree that produced them, people often return to their origins. The phrase captures the pull of one's homeland. Modern usage describes returning to one's birthplace or origins, especially after spending years away, recognizing the deep connection to where one began.
metaphoric_meaning: Return to one's roots; go back home
description_tr: This idiom describes falling (落) leaves (葉) returning (歸) to their roots (根). Just as leaves fall and nourish the tree that produced them, people often return to their origins. The phrase captures the pull of one's homeland. Modern usage describes returning to one's birthplace or origins, especially after spending years away, recognizing the deep connection to where one began.
chineseExample_tr: 在海外多年後，他落葉歸根，回到家鄉退休。

example: Despite the opportunities elsewhere, he couldn't bring himself to leave.
chineseExample: 尽管别处有机会，他仍故土难离。
description: This idiom describes native (故) soil (土) being hard (难) to leave (离). It captures the emotional attachment to one's homeland that makes departure difficult. The phrase recognizes the deep bonds between people and places. Modern usage describes the difficulty of leaving one's hometown or country, the pull of familiar places and people that makes relocation emotionally challenging.
description_tr: This idiom describes native (故) soil (土) being hard (難) to leave (離). It captures the emotional attachment to one's homeland that makes departure difficult. The phrase recognizes the deep bonds between people and places. Modern usage describes the difficulty of leaving one's hometown or country, the pull of familiar places and people that makes relocation emotionally challenging.
chineseExample_tr: 儘管別處有機會，他仍故土難離。

meaning: Content with soil, reluctant to move
example: Rural communities often maintain strong attachment to their land.
chineseExample: 农村社区往往安土重迁，对土地有强烈的依恋。
description: This idiom describes being content (安) with one's land (土) and reluctant (重) to relocate (迁). It reflects traditional agricultural societies where land was life and moving was avoided. The phrase captures conservative attachment to place. Modern usage describes the preference for stability over change, the reluctance to leave familiar surroundings even for potential improvements.
description_tr: This idiom describes being content (安) with one's land (土) and reluctant (重) to relocate (遷). It reflects traditional agricultural societies where land was life and moving was avoided. The phrase captures conservative attachment to place. Modern usage describes the preference for stability over change, the reluctance to leave familiar surroundings even for potential improvements.
chineseExample_tr: 農村社區往往安土重遷，對土地有強烈的依戀。

example: The era was characterized by unprecedented peace and prosperity.
chineseExample: 那个时代四海升平，前所未有的和平繁荣。
description: This idiom describes the four seas (四海) - meaning the whole world in classical Chinese - rising (升) in peace (平). It depicts universal peace and harmony across all lands. The phrase was used to describe golden ages of good governance. Modern usage describes periods of widespread peace and prosperity, idealized times when conflicts cease and people live well.
description_tr: This idiom describes the four seas (四海) - meaning the whole world in classical Chinese - rising (昇) in peace (平). It depicts universal peace and harmony across all lands. The phrase was used to describe golden ages of good governance. Modern usage describes periods of widespread peace and prosperity, idealized times when conflicts cease and people live well.
chineseExample_tr: 那個時代四海昇平，前所未有的和平繁榮。

example: The country enjoyed decades of stability and growth.
chineseExample: 国家享受了数十年的太平盛世。
description: This idiom describes a time of great (太) peace (平) and flourishing (盛) era (世). It depicts the ideal society - peaceful, prosperous, and stable. Such periods were associated with virtuous rule. Modern usage describes golden ages of any nation or organization, times characterized by stability, growth, and general well-being for the population.
metaphoric_meaning: Golden age of peace and prosperity
description_tr: This idiom describes a time of great (太) peace (平) and flourishing (盛) era (世). It depicts the ideal society - peaceful, prosperous, and stable. Such periods were associated with virtuous rule. Modern usage describes golden ages of any nation or organization, times characterized by stability, growth, and general well-being for the population.
chineseExample_tr: 國家享受了數十年的太平盛世。

example: Good governance should prioritize national stability and citizen welfare.
chineseExample: 良好的治理应该以国泰民安为首要目标。
description: This idiom describes the country (国) being peaceful (泰) and the people (民) being safe (安). It represents the ideal outcome of good governance where both the state and citizens thrive. The phrase was used in blessings and praise for rulers. Modern usage describes political stability combined with public welfare, the fundamental goal of governance.
description_tr: This idiom describes the country (國) being peaceful (泰) and the people (民) being safe (安). It represents the ideal outcome of good governance where both the state and citizens thrive. The phrase was used in blessings and praise for rulers. Modern usage describes political stability combined with public welfare, the fundamental goal of governance.
chineseExample_tr: 良好的治理應該以國泰民安為首要目標。

example: Economic development benefits both citizens and national power.
chineseExample: 经济发展使民富国强。
description: This idiom describes the people (民) being wealthy (富) and the country (国) being strong (强). It recognizes that national strength comes from citizen prosperity. The phrase appeared in texts on governance emphasizing that enriching the people was the path to state power. Modern usage describes successful development where economic growth lifts both individuals and the nation.
description_tr: This idiom describes the people (民) being wealthy (富) and the country (國) being strong (強). It recognizes that national strength comes from citizen prosperity. The phrase appeared in texts on governance emphasizing that enriching the people was the path to state power. Modern usage describes successful development where economic growth lifts both individuals and the nation.
chineseExample_tr: 經濟發展使民富國強。

example: The new administration committed to reforms and better governance.
chineseExample: 新政府励精图治，致力于改革和更好的治理。
description: This idiom describes exerting (励) one's essence (精) and planning (图) governance (治). It depicts dedicated, energetic effort to govern well. The phrase was used to describe rulers who worked diligently on state affairs. Modern usage describes determined efforts at reform and improvement, whether in government, organizations, or personal endeavors.
description_tr: This idiom describes exerting (勵) one's essence (精) and planning (圖) governance (治). It depicts dedicated, energetic effort to govern well. The phrase was used to describe rulers who worked diligently on state affairs. Modern usage describes determined efforts at reform and improvement, whether in government, organizations, or personal endeavors.
chineseExample_tr: 新政府勵精圖治，致力於改革和更好的治理。

example: He dedicated himself completely to the cause.
chineseExample: 他披肝沥胆，全身心投入这项事业。
description: This idiom describes exposing (披) one's liver (肝) and draining (沥) one's gallbladder (胆). These organs represent sincerity and courage in Chinese culture. The phrase depicts holding nothing back, giving everything. Modern usage describes complete dedication and openness, offering one's full effort and being completely honest, hiding nothing in pursuit of a goal.
metaphoric_meaning: Give one's all; be completely sincere
description_tr: This idiom describes exposing (披) one's liver (肝) and draining (瀝) one's gallbladder (膽). These organs represent sincerity and courage in Chinese culture. The phrase depicts holding nothing back, giving everything. Modern usage describes complete dedication and openness, offering one's full effort and being completely honest, hiding nothing in pursuit of a goal.
chineseExample_tr: 他披肝瀝膽，全身心投入這項事業。

example: He served the organization until his final breath.
chineseExample: 他鞠躬尽瘁，为组织服务到最后一刻。
description: This idiom describes bowing (鞠躬) and exhausting (尽) oneself (瘁). It comes from Zhuge Liang's famous memorial, describing his dedication to serving Shu until death. The phrase embodies the ultimate in loyal service. Modern usage describes complete dedication to a cause or organization, giving everything until nothing remains, the highest form of devoted service.
metaphoric_meaning: Devote oneself completely; work until exhaustion
description_tr: This idiom describes bowing (鞠躬) and exhausting (盡) oneself (瘁). It comes from Zhuge Liang's famous memorial, describing his dedication to serving Shu until death. The phrase embodies the ultimate in loyal service. Modern usage describes complete dedication to a cause or organization, giving everything until nothing remains, the highest form of devoted service.
chineseExample_tr: 他鞠躬盡瘁，為組織服務到最後一刻。

example: His commitment to justice continued until his last day.
chineseExample: 他对正义的追求死而后已。
description: This idiom describes stopping (已) only after (后) death (死). Often paired with 鞠躬尽瘁, it completes Zhuge Liang's famous statement of lifelong dedication. The phrase represents commitment that only death can end. Modern usage describes unwavering dedication to principles or causes, the resolve to continue fighting until one's final breath.
description_tr: This idiom describes stopping (已) only after (後) death (死). Often paired with 鞠躬盡瘁, it completes Zhuge Liang's famous statement of lifelong dedication. The phrase represents commitment that only death can end. Modern usage describes unwavering dedication to principles or causes, the resolve to continue fighting until one's final breath.
chineseExample_tr: 他對正義的追求死而後已。

example: Achieving sustainability is a long-term challenge requiring sustained effort.
chineseExample: 实现可持续发展任重道远。
description: This idiom describes heavy (重) responsibility (任) and a long (远) road (道). From the Analects where Confucius described the burden of benevolence. The phrase captures the weight of important duties that require long journeys. Modern usage describes significant undertakings that require sustained effort over time, acknowledging both the importance and difficulty of major goals.
metaphoric_meaning: Heavy burden and long journey ahead
description_tr: This idiom describes heavy (重) responsibility (任) and a long (遠) road (道). From the Analects where Confucius described the burden of benevolence. The phrase captures the weight of important duties that require long journeys. Modern usage describes significant undertakings that require sustained effort over time, acknowledging both the importance and difficulty of major goals.
chineseExample_tr: 實現可持續發展任重道遠。

example: She traveled from far away to attend her friend's wedding.
chineseExample: 她千里迢迢赶来参加朋友的婚礼。
description: This idiom describes a thousand (千) miles (里) being distant (迢迢). The doubled 迢 emphasizes the remoteness and length of the journey. The phrase captures the effort of traveling great distances. Modern usage describes coming from far away, emphasizing the dedication shown by traveling long distances for a purpose, whether visiting loved ones or pursuing goals.
description_tr: This idiom describes a thousand (千) miles (里) being distant (迢迢). The doubled 迢 emphasizes the remoteness and length of the journey. The phrase captures the effort of traveling great distances. Modern usage describes coming from far away, emphasizing the dedication shown by traveling long distances for a purpose, whether visiting loved ones or pursuing goals.
chineseExample_tr: 她千里迢迢趕來參加朋友的婚禮。

meaning: Eat in wind, sleep in dew
example: The explorers endured harsh conditions during their expedition.
chineseExample: 探险队员风餐露宿，忍受着艰苦的条件。
description: This idiom describes eating (餐) in the wind (风) and sleeping (宿) in the dew (露). It depicts the hardships of travelers or workers without shelter, exposed to the elements. The phrase captures the difficulties of life on the road. Modern usage describes enduring harsh conditions, the willingness to suffer discomfort in pursuit of goals.
metaphoric_meaning: Endure hardships of travel; rough it
description_tr: This idiom describes eating (餐) in the wind (風) and sleeping (宿) in the dew (露). It depicts the hardships of travelers or workers without shelter, exposed to the elements. The phrase captures the difficulties of life on the road. Modern usage describes enduring harsh conditions, the willingness to suffer discomfort in pursuit of goals.
chineseExample_tr: 探險隊員風餐露宿，忍受著艱苦的條件。

example: They overcame many obstacles to reach their destination.
chineseExample: 他们跋山涉水，克服重重困难到达目的地。
description: This idiom describes climbing (跋) mountains (山) and fording (涉) waters (水). It depicts arduous travel through difficult terrain. The phrase captures the determination needed to overcome physical obstacles. Modern usage describes overcoming difficulties, the perseverance required to reach goals despite obstacles, whether literal journeys or metaphorical challenges.
description_tr: This idiom describes climbing (跋) mountains (山) and fording (涉) waters (水). It depicts arduous travel through difficult terrain. The phrase captures the determination needed to overcome physical obstacles. Modern usage describes overcoming difficulties, the perseverance required to reach goals despite obstacles, whether literal journeys or metaphorical challenges.
chineseExample_tr: 他們跋山涉水，克服重重困難到達目的地。

example: The postal workers delivered mail despite the mountainous terrain.
chineseExample: 邮递员翻山越岭送信。
description: This idiom describes crossing (翻) mountains (山) and passing (越) ridges (岭). Similar to 跋山涉水, it emphasizes mountainous terrain specifically. The phrase captures the physical challenge of mountain travel. Modern usage describes overcoming difficult challenges, often highlighting the effort involved in reaching remote places or achieving difficult goals.
metaphoric_meaning: Cross difficult terrain; overcome major obstacles
description_tr: This idiom describes crossing (翻) mountains (山) and passing (越) ridges (嶺). Similar to 跋山涉水, it emphasizes mountainous terrain specifically. The phrase captures the physical challenge of mountain travel. Modern usage describes overcoming difficult challenges, often highlighting the effort involved in reaching remote places or achieving difficult goals.
chineseExample_tr: 郵遞員翻山越嶺送信。

meaning: Not consider a thousand miles far
example: He traveled across the country just to see her.
chineseExample: 他不远千里，穿越全国只为见她一面。
description: This idiom describes not (不) considering far (远) a thousand (千) miles (里). From Mencius describing the willingness to travel great distances for important purposes. The phrase emphasizes determination that overcomes distance. Modern usage describes the dedication shown by those willing to travel far, the commitment that makes physical distance irrelevant.
metaphoric_meaning: Willingly travel far; make great efforts
description_tr: This idiom describes not (不) considering far (遠) a thousand (千) miles (里). From Mencius describing the willingness to travel great distances for important purposes. The phrase emphasizes determination that overcomes distance. Modern usage describes the dedication shown by those willing to travel far, the commitment that makes physical distance irrelevant.
chineseExample_tr: 他不遠千里，穿越全國只為見她一面。

example: His impatience for quick results led to poor decisions.
chineseExample: 他急于求成导致了糟糕的决定。
description: This idiom describes being anxious (急) about (于) seeking (求) success (成). It warns against impatience that undermines careful progress. The phrase cautions that rushing toward goals often backfires. Modern usage criticizes the desire for quick results at the expense of proper process, the counterproductive impatience that sacrifices quality for speed.
metaphoric_meaning: Be impatient for success; rush things
description_tr: This idiom describes being anxious (急) about (於) seeking (求) success (成). It warns against impatience that undermines careful progress. The phrase cautions that rushing toward goals often backfires. Modern usage criticizes the desire for quick results at the expense of proper process, the counterproductive impatience that sacrifices quality for speed.
chineseExample_tr: 他急於求成導致了糟糕的決定。

example: Rushing the project caused more delays in the end.
chineseExample: 赶工反而导致了更多延误，真是欲速不达。
description: This idiom describes desiring (欲) speed (速) but not (不) reaching (达) the goal. From the Analects where Confucius warned that haste impedes rather than helps. The phrase captures the paradox that rushing often slows progress. Modern usage warns against impatience, recognizing that sustainable achievement requires appropriate pacing rather than desperate rushing.
metaphoric_meaning: Haste makes waste; more haste less speed
description_tr: This idiom describes desiring (欲) speed (速) but not (不) reaching (達) the goal. From the Analects where Confucius warned that haste impedes rather than helps. The phrase captures the paradox that rushing often slows progress. Modern usage warns against impatience, recognizing that sustainable achievement requires appropriate pacing rather than desperate rushing.
chineseExample_tr: 趕工反而導致了更多延誤，真是欲速不達。

example: Learning a language requires steady, gradual progress.
chineseExample: 学习语言需要循序渐进。
description: This idiom describes following (循) sequence (序) and gradually (渐) advancing (进). It advocates for systematic, step-by-step progress rather than jumping ahead. The phrase appeared in classical texts on education emphasizing proper ordering. Modern usage describes methodical approaches to learning or development, recognizing that solid foundations enable sustainable progress.
metaphoric_meaning: Proceed step by step; progress gradually
description_tr: This idiom describes following (循) sequence (序) and gradually (漸) advancing (進). It advocates for systematic, step-by-step progress rather than jumping ahead. The phrase appeared in classical texts on education emphasizing proper ordering. Modern usage describes methodical approaches to learning or development, recognizing that solid foundations enable sustainable progress.
chineseExample_tr: 學習語言需要循序漸進。

example: The project proceeded according to the established process.
chineseExample: 项目按部就班地推进。
description: This idiom describes following (按) departments (部) and going to (就) classes (班). Originally describing bureaucratic procedures, it came to mean following established order. The phrase values systematic approaches over improvisation. Modern usage describes following proper procedures and sequences, working methodically rather than chaotically, though sometimes criticizes excessive rigidity.
description_tr: This idiom describes following (按) departments (部) and going to (就) classes (班). Originally describing bureaucratic procedures, it came to mean following established order. The phrase values systematic approaches over improvisation. Modern usage describes following proper procedures and sequences, working methodically rather than chaotically, though sometimes criticizes excessive rigidity.
chineseExample_tr: 項目按部就班地推進。

example: His practical approach helped him build a successful career.
chineseExample: 他脚踏实地的做法帮助他建立了成功的事业。
description: This idiom describes feet (脚) stepping (踏) on solid (实) ground (地). It depicts practical, grounded action rather than flights of fancy. The phrase values realistic, down-to-earth approaches. Modern usage praises practical people who focus on concrete actions rather than empty dreams, building success through steady, realistic effort rather than speculation.
description_tr: This idiom describes feet (腳) stepping (踏) on solid (實) ground (地). It depicts practical, grounded action rather than flights of fancy. The phrase values realistic, down-to-earth approaches. Modern usage praises practical people who focus on concrete actions rather than empty dreams, building success through steady, realistic effort rather than speculation.
chineseExample_tr: 他腳踏實地的做法幫助他建立了成功的事業。

example: The company grew through careful, steady expansion.
chineseExample: 公司稳扎稳打，稳步扩张。
description: This idiom describes establishing stable (稳) camps (扎) and making stable (稳) attacks (打). From military strategy emphasizing secure foundations before advancing. The phrase advocates consolidation over reckless advance. Modern usage describes careful, conservative approaches that secure gains before moving forward, prioritizing stability over speed.
description_tr: This idiom describes establishing stable (穩) camps (扎) and making stable (穩) attacks (打). From military strategy emphasizing secure foundations before advancing. The phrase advocates consolidation over reckless advance. Modern usage describes careful, conservative approaches that secure gains before moving forward, prioritizing stability over speed.
chineseExample_tr: 公司穩扎穩打，穩步擴張。

example: With such a strong lead, victory seemed certain.
chineseExample: 有了这么大的领先优势，他们稳操胜券。
description: This idiom describes firmly (稳) holding (操) the winning (胜) ticket (券). It depicts having victory virtually assured, like holding a winning lottery ticket. The phrase expresses confidence in certain success. Modern usage describes situations where success seems guaranteed, when one has such overwhelming advantage that failure appears impossible.
metaphoric_meaning: Have victory in the bag; be certain to win
description_tr: This idiom describes firmly (穩) holding (操) the winning (勝) ticket (券). It depicts having victory virtually assured, like holding a winning lottery ticket. The phrase expresses confidence in certain success. Modern usage describes situations where success seems guaranteed, when one has such overwhelming advantage that failure appears impossible.
chineseExample_tr: 有了這麼大的領先優勢，他們穩操勝券。

example: The team felt confident going into the final round.
chineseExample: 球队胜券在握地进入决赛。
description: This idiom describes the victory (胜) ticket (券) being in (在) one's grasp (握). Similar to 稳操胜券, it depicts assured victory. The phrase expresses confidence that success is already secured. Modern usage describes situations where one feels certain of winning, when all factors point toward inevitable success.
metaphoric_meaning: Have victory assured; be confident of winning
description_tr: This idiom describes the victory (勝) ticket (券) being in (在) one's grasp (握). Similar to 穩操勝券, it depicts assured victory. The phrase expresses confidence that success is already secured. Modern usage describes situations where one feels certain of winning, when all factors point toward inevitable success.
chineseExample_tr: 球隊勝券在握地進入決賽。

meaning: Circumstances demand it must be done
example: Digital transformation has become inevitable for the industry.
chineseExample: 数字化转型已势在必行。
description: This idiom describes circumstances (势) being such that (在) action must (必) be taken (行). It depicts situations where conditions make action unavoidable. The phrase recognizes when forces require response. Modern usage describes imperatives - situations where change has become necessary regardless of preferences, when adaptation is required for survival.
description_tr: This idiom describes circumstances (勢) being such that (在) action must (必) be taken (行). It depicts situations where conditions make action unavoidable. The phrase recognizes when forces require response. Modern usage describes imperatives - situations where change has become necessary regardless of preferences, when adaptation is required for survival.
chineseExample_tr: 數字化轉型已勢在必行。

example: Once they gained momentum, nothing could stop their advance.
chineseExample: 一旦获得势头，他们的进攻势如破竹。
description: This idiom describes momentum (势) like (如) splitting (破) bamboo (竹). When bamboo is split, the crack runs easily down the length. The phrase captures unstoppable momentum where each success makes the next easier. Modern usage describes winning streaks and momentum-driven success, situations where progress becomes increasingly easy as barriers fall.
metaphoric_meaning: Have irresistible momentum; sweep all before one
description_tr: This idiom describes momentum (勢) like (如) splitting (破) bamboo (竹). When bamboo is split, the crack runs easily down the length. The phrase captures unstoppable momentum where each success makes the next easier. Modern usage describes winning streaks and momentum-driven success, situations where progress becomes increasingly easy as barriers fall.
chineseExample_tr: 一旦獲得勢頭，他們的進攻勢如破竹。

example: Their championship team dominated every opponent.
chineseExample: 他们的冠军球队所向披靡。
description: This idiom describes wherever (所) directed (向), all fall (披靡). It depicts an unstoppable force that defeats everything in its path. The phrase was used for victorious armies that conquered all opposition. Modern usage describes overwhelming dominance in any field - sports teams that win every game, businesses that defeat all competitors.
description_tr: This idiom describes wherever (所) directed (向), all fall (披靡). It depicts an unstoppable force that defeats everything in its path. The phrase was used for victorious armies that conquered all opposition. Modern usage describes overwhelming dominance in any field - sports teams that win every game, businesses that defeat all competitors.
chineseExample_tr: 他們的冠軍球隊所向披靡。

example: At his peak, no competitor could challenge him.
chineseExample: 在巅峰时期，他所向无敌。
description: This idiom describes wherever (所) directed (向), having no (无) enemies (敌). Similar to 所向披靡, it depicts invincibility. The phrase emphasizes the absence of worthy opposition rather than their defeat. Modern usage describes peak dominance when one has no real competitors, periods when superiority is so complete that challenges don't arise.
description_tr: This idiom describes wherever (所) directed (向), having no (無) enemies (敵). Similar to 所向披靡, it depicts invincibility. The phrase emphasizes the absence of worthy opposition rather than their defeat. Modern usage describes peak dominance when one has no real competitors, periods when superiority is so complete that challenges don't arise.
chineseExample_tr: 在巔峰時期，他所向無敵。

example: The army had never lost a battle.
chineseExample: 这支军队攻无不克。
description: This idiom describes attacks (攻) having nothing (无) not (不) conquered (克). It depicts military forces that succeed in every assault. The phrase was used for armies with perfect records. Modern usage describes consistent success in any competitive endeavor, teams or individuals who achieve every goal they attempt.
metaphoric_meaning: Win every battle; never fail in attacks
description_tr: This idiom describes attacks (攻) having nothing (無) not (不) conquered (克). It depicts military forces that succeed in every assault. The phrase was used for armies with perfect records. Modern usage describes consistent success in any competitive endeavor, teams or individuals who achieve every goal they attempt.
chineseExample_tr: 這支軍隊攻無不克。

example: Their legal team has never lost a case.
chineseExample: 他们的法律团队战无不胜。
description: This idiom describes battles (战) having nothing (无) not (不) won (胜). Similar to 攻无不克, it depicts perfect military success. Often used together as 攻无不克战无不胜 for emphasis. Modern usage describes undefeated records in any competition, consistent victory in whatever challenges arise.
description_tr: This idiom describes battles (戰) having nothing (無) not (不) won (勝). Similar to 攻無不克, it depicts perfect military success. Often used together as 攻無不克戰無不勝 for emphasis. Modern usage describes undefeated records in any competition, consistent victory in whatever challenges arise.
chineseExample_tr: 他們的法律團隊戰無不勝。

example: The new product launch was immediately successful.
chineseExample: 新产品发布旗开得胜。
description: This idiom describes flags (旗) opening (开) and obtaining (得) victory (胜). It depicts winning immediately upon starting, like an army victorious in its first battle. The phrase was used as a blessing for new ventures. Modern usage describes auspicious beginnings, initial successes that set positive momentum for what follows.
metaphoric_meaning: Win at the very start; immediate success
description_tr: This idiom describes flags (旗) opening (開) and obtaining (得) victory (勝). It depicts winning immediately upon starting, like an army victorious in its first battle. The phrase was used as a blessing for new ventures. Modern usage describes auspicious beginnings, initial successes that set positive momentum for what follows.
chineseExample_tr: 新產品發布旗開得勝。

example: May all your endeavors succeed quickly!
chineseExample: 祝你马到成功！
description: This idiom describes when the horse (马) arrives (到), success (成功) is achieved. It depicts swift victory, success that comes as quickly as a galloping horse. The phrase is commonly used as a blessing for new endeavors. Modern usage wishes someone rapid success, expressing hope that their ventures will succeed quickly and easily.
description_tr: This idiom describes when the horse (馬) arrives (到), success (成功) is achieved. It depicts swift victory, success that comes as quickly as a galloping horse. The phrase is commonly used as a blessing for new endeavors. Modern usage wishes someone rapid success, expressing hope that their ventures will succeed quickly and easily.
chineseExample_tr: 祝你馬到成功！

example: May your journey through life be smooth and successful.
chineseExample: 愿你的人生一帆风顺。
description: This idiom describes one (一) sail (帆) with favorable (顺) wind (风). It depicts a sailing voyage blessed with perfect winds requiring no struggle. The phrase is a common blessing wishing smooth progress. Modern usage wishes someone easy success, a life or endeavor free from obstacles, where everything goes smoothly.
description_tr: This idiom describes one (一) sail (帆) with favorable (順) wind (風). It depicts a sailing voyage blessed with perfect winds requiring no struggle. The phrase is a common blessing wishing smooth progress. Modern usage wishes someone easy success, a life or endeavor free from obstacles, where everything goes smoothly.
chineseExample_tr: 願你的人生一帆風順。

example: His rapid promotion took everyone by surprise.
chineseExample: 他的快速晋升让所有人惊讶，简直平步青云。
description: This idiom describes level (平) steps (步) to blue (青) clouds (云). It depicts rising to great heights with ease, as if walking casually into the sky. The phrase describes effortless ascent to high positions. Modern usage describes rapid, seemingly effortless career advancement, meteoric rises to success.
description_tr: This idiom describes level (平) steps (步) to blue (青) clouds (雲). It depicts rising to great heights with ease, as if walking casually into the sky. The phrase describes effortless ascent to high positions. Modern usage describes rapid, seemingly effortless career advancement, meteoric rises to success.
chineseExample_tr: 他的快速晉升讓所有人驚訝，簡直平步青雲。

example: She rose from humble beginnings to great success.
chineseExample: 她从贫寒起步飞黄腾达。
description: This idiom describes the flying (飞) yellow horse (黄) soaring (腾达). The yellow horse was a legendary swift steed. The phrase depicts rapid rise to prominence and success. Modern usage describes spectacular career advancement, rising quickly from obscurity to fame and fortune.
metaphoric_meaning: Rise to fame and fortune rapidly
description_tr: This idiom describes the flying (飛) yellow horse (黃) soaring (騰達). The yellow horse was a legendary swift steed. The phrase depicts rapid rise to prominence and success. Modern usage describes spectacular career advancement, rising quickly from obscurity to fame and fortune.
chineseExample_tr: 她從貧寒起步飛黃騰達。

example: Stock prices soared after the announcement.
chineseExample: 公告后股价扶摇直上。
description: This idiom describes riding a whirlwind (扶摇) straight (直) up (上). From Zhuangzi's description of the roc bird rising ninety thousand li on the wind. The phrase depicts rapid, dramatic ascent. Modern usage describes meteoric rises - in careers, stock prices, or any measure that climbs dramatically and quickly.
description_tr: This idiom describes riding a whirlwind (扶搖) straight (直) up (上). From Zhuangzi's description of the roc bird rising ninety thousand li on the wind. The phrase depicts rapid, dramatic ascent. Modern usage describes meteoric rises - in careers, stock prices, or any measure that climbs dramatically and quickly.
chineseExample_tr: 公告後股價扶搖直上。

example: Her talent propelled her rapidly through the ranks.
chineseExample: 她的才华让她青云直上。
description: This idiom describes going straight (直) up (上) to blue (青) clouds (云). Similar to 平步青云, it depicts rapid ascent to high positions. The directness of 直 emphasizes the speed and lack of detours. Modern usage describes rapid promotion and career advancement, rising directly to the top without setbacks.
description_tr: This idiom describes going straight (直) up (上) to blue (青) clouds (雲). Similar to 平步青雲, it depicts rapid ascent to high positions. The directness of 直 emphasizes the speed and lack of detours. Modern usage describes rapid promotion and career advancement, rising directly to the top without setbacks.
chineseExample_tr: 她的才華讓她青雲直上。

example: May your career continue to advance steadily.
chineseExample: 祝你事业步步高升。
description: This idiom describes step (步) by step (步) rising (升) high (高). Unlike rapid ascent idioms, this depicts steady, continuous advancement. Each step brings higher position. The phrase is a common blessing for career success. Modern usage wishes someone continued promotion and advancement, steady progress rather than sudden jumps.
description_tr: This idiom describes step (步) by step (步) rising (升) high (高). Unlike rapid ascent idioms, this depicts steady, continuous advancement. Each step brings higher position. The phrase is a common blessing for career success. Modern usage wishes someone continued promotion and advancement, steady progress rather than sudden jumps.
chineseExample_tr: 祝你事業步步高升。

example: The bestselling author achieved both recognition and wealth.
chineseExample: 畅销作家名利双收。
description: This idiom describes fame (名) and profit (利) both (双) obtained (收). It depicts the ideal outcome where one gains both reputation and financial reward. The phrase represents complete worldly success. Modern usage describes those fortunate enough to achieve both recognition and wealth, the rare combination of artistic and commercial success.
description_tr: This idiom describes fame (名) and profit (利) both (雙) obtained (收). It depicts the ideal outcome where one gains both reputation and financial reward. The phrase represents complete worldly success. Modern usage describes those fortunate enough to achieve both recognition and wealth, the rare combination of artistic and commercial success.
chineseExample_tr: 暢銷作家名利雙收。

example: After decades of work, he finally achieved recognition.
chineseExample: 经过数十年的努力，他终于功成名就。
description: This idiom describes merit (功) achieved (成) and name (名) established (就). It depicts the completion of one's life work and the establishment of lasting reputation. The phrase represents the culmination of a successful career. Modern usage describes reaching the pinnacle of one's profession, achieving the goals and recognition that define a successful life.
description_tr: This idiom describes merit (功) achieved (成) and name (名) established (就). It depicts the completion of one's life work and the establishment of lasting reputation. The phrase represents the culmination of a successful career. Modern usage describes reaching the pinnacle of one's profession, achieving the goals and recognition that define a successful life.
chineseExample_tr: 經過數十年的努力，他終於功成名就。

example: After completing his mission, he quietly stepped aside.
chineseExample: 完成使命后，他功成身退。
description: This idiom describes merit (功) achieved (成) and the person (身) withdrawing (退). From the Dao De Jing advising that the wise withdraw after accomplishing their work. The phrase embodies the wisdom of knowing when to step back. Modern usage describes graceful exits after achievement, the wisdom of retiring at one's peak rather than overstaying.
description_tr: This idiom describes merit (功) achieved (成) and the person (身) withdrawing (退). From the Dao De Jing advising that the wise withdraw after accomplishing their work. The phrase embodies the wisdom of knowing when to step back. Modern usage describes graceful exits after achievement, the wisdom of retiring at one's peak rather than overstaying.
chineseExample_tr: 完成使命後，他功成身退。

example: He wisely left the company at the height of success.
chineseExample: 他明智地在事业巅峰急流勇退。
description: This idiom describes bravely (勇) retreating (退) from a rapid (急) current (流). It depicts the wisdom and courage needed to withdraw while circumstances are favorable. The phrase values knowing when to stop rather than being swept away. Modern usage describes the rare wisdom of leaving at one's peak, retiring from success before decline.
metaphoric_meaning: Retire at the peak; know when to quit
description_tr: This idiom describes bravely (勇) retreating (退) from a rapid (急) current (流). It depicts the wisdom and courage needed to withdraw while circumstances are favorable. The phrase values knowing when to stop rather than being swept away. Modern usage describes the rare wisdom of leaving at one's peak, retiring from success before decline.
chineseExample_tr: 他明智地在事業巔峰急流勇退。

example: Knowing when to take profits is key in investing.
chineseExample: 在投资中，见好就收是关键。
description: This idiom describes seeing (见) good conditions (好) and then (就) collecting/stopping (收). It advises knowing when to quit while ahead rather than pushing luck too far. The phrase embodies practical wisdom about limits. Modern usage advocates for taking gains when available, the prudence of securing success rather than risking it for more.
description_tr: This idiom describes seeing (見) good conditions (好) and then (就) collecting/stopping (收). It advises knowing when to quit while ahead rather than pushing luck too far. The phrase embodies practical wisdom about limits. Modern usage advocates for taking gains when available, the prudence of securing success rather than risking it for more.
chineseExample_tr: 在投資中，見好就收是關鍵。

example: Moderation in all things is the path to balance.
chineseExample: 凡事适可而止才能保持平衡。
description: This idiom describes when appropriate (适可) then (而) stopping (止). It advocates for moderation and knowing limits. The phrase warns against excess and overindulgence. Modern usage advises stopping at the right point - eating until satisfied not stuffed, drinking in moderation, working hard but not to burnout.
metaphoric_meaning: Stop at the right point; practice moderation
description_tr: This idiom describes when appropriate (適可) then (而) stopping (止). It advocates for moderation and knowing limits. The phrase warns against excess and overindulgence. Modern usage advises stopping at the right point - eating until satisfied not stuffed, drinking in moderation, working hard but not to burnout.
chineseExample_tr: 凡事適可而止才能保持平衡。

example: The seasoning was perfect - not too much, not too little.
chineseExample: 调味恰到好处，不多不少。
description: This idiom describes being exactly (恰) at (到) the good (好) place (处). It depicts hitting the perfect point - neither too much nor too little. The phrase values precision and appropriateness. Modern usage describes things done with perfect calibration, actions or amounts that are exactly right for the situation.
description_tr: This idiom describes being exactly (恰) at (到) the good (好) place (處). It depicts hitting the perfect point - neither too much nor too little. The phrase values precision and appropriateness. Modern usage describes things done with perfect calibration, actions or amounts that are exactly right for the situation.
chineseExample_tr: 調味恰到好處，不多不少。

example: His response was perfectly measured and appropriate.
chineseExample: 他的回应恰如其分。
description: This idiom describes being exactly (恰) as (如) its (其) proper portion (分).
